claim: You can watch the Borgia's World of Wonders before Ludacris's Release Therapy finishes.

supporting.text: Ludacris's Release Therapy has a runtime of approximately 60 minutes, while Borgia's World of Wonders is a full-length feature film, typically exceeding 90 minutes.

attacks.text: Ludacris's Release Therapy has a runtime of approximately 60 minutes, while Borgia's World of Wonders is a full-length feature film, typically exceeding 90 minutes.
Borgia's World of Wonders could have a shorter runtime if it is an edited or abridged version.
Abridged versions of full-length feature films are rare and often not officially released.
Release Therapy might have bonus tracks or extended content that increases its runtime beyond 60 minutes.
Standard editions of Release Therapy are well-documented to have a runtime of approximately 60 minutes, with extended versions being rare.

supporting.text: Release Therapy was released in 2006, predating Borgia's World of Wonders by several years, making it impossible to watch the latter before the former was finished.

attacks.text: Release Therapy was released in 2006, predating Borgia's World of Wonders by several years, making it impossible to watch the latter before the former was finished.
Borgia's World of Wonders could have been released earlier in some regions or formats, allowing for overlapping availability with Release Therapy.
There is no documented evidence of Borgia's World of Wonders being released before 2006 in any region or format.
The claim might refer to watching a pre-release or unfinished version of Borgia's World of Wonders before Release Therapy was completed.
Pre-release versions are typically not available to the public, making this scenario highly unlikely.

supporting.text: The claim implies a temporal overlap that does not exist, as the two works were released in different years and have no direct chronological connection.

attacks.text: The claim implies a temporal overlap that does not exist, as the two works were released in different years and have no direct chronological connection.
The claim does not specify a requirement for the works to be released in the same year; it only compares their durations.
Even if the works were released in different years, the claim could still hold if one's duration is shorter than the other's.
The durations of the works are not provided, making it impossible to verify the claim's validity.

supporting.text: Given the typical duration of albums and films, it is highly unlikely that a full film could be watched before an album finishes playing.

attacks.text: Given the typical duration of albums and films, it is highly unlikely that a full film could be watched before an album finishes playing.
Some albums, like Ludacris's Release Therapy, are shorter than average (around 45 minutes), while some films can be as short as 60 minutes, making it possible under certain conditions.
Even with shorter films, accounting for pre-film ads or delays would likely extend the total viewing time beyond the album's duration.
Streaming platforms allow skipping intros or credits, reducing the effective runtime of the film.
Skipping content may not be universally applicable (e.g., in theaters or due to platform restrictions).
